Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They support a mentee facing a high-stakes project that could determine their future career trajectory.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s voice echoing in my mind as she reminded me how important it was for me to lead the upcoming family ceremony. “It’s your turn to carry on our tradition,” she said, her eyes shining with pride and expectation. I knew how much this meant to her, to all of them. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from Priya, my mentee at work. She was anxious about her presentation tomorrow—the one that could open doors for her career. She needed my guidance, my presence, and I had promised to help her rehearse, to be there for her in this crucial moment.

The weight of both worlds pressed on me. My family expected me to honor our heritage, to be the son who keeps our values alive. Priya needed me to be the mentor who believed in her, who wouldn’t let her down. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I turned. My heart raced as I stared at the calendar, the two commitments staring back at me, impossible to reconcile.
